COURSE SYLLABUS First Semester, AY 2020-2021 Lecture √ Course GNED 10 Course Title Gender and Society Type Laboratory Credit Units 3 Code ___ This course critically examines the ways gender informs the social world in which we live. This course exposes the "common- Course Description sense" world of gender around us; considers how we develop our gendered identities; explores the workings of the institutions that shape our gendered lives; and leads to an understanding of the relationship between gender and the social structure Lecture: ______________________________ Pre- None Course Schedule Laboratory: ______________________________ requisites

TRUTH is demonstrated by the student’s objectivity and honesty during examinations, class activities and in the development of projects. Core Values EXCELLENCE is exhibited by the students’ self-confidence, punctuality, diligence and commitment in the assigned tasks, class performance and other course requirements.

Students are expected to live by and stand for the following University tenets:
TRUTH is demonstrated by the student’s objectivity and honesty during examinations, class activities and in the development of projects. Core Values EXCELLENCE is exhibited by the students’ self-confidence, punctuality, diligence and commitment in the assigned tasks, class performance and other course requirements.
SERVICE is manifested by the students’ respect, rapport, fairness and cooperation in dealing with their peers and members of

the community. In addition, they should exhibit love and respect for nature and support for the cause of humanity.
The three campuses shall endeavour to achieve the following goals: Goals of the 1) Provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright, and globally competitive graduates; College/ 2) Develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences and technology support instruction; and Campus 3) Develop and conduct extension activities that will empower people and communities.
The Department of Arts and Sciences shall endeavor to:
1. Uphold the highest standards in delivering quality and gender-sensitive instruction through continuous development of its Objectives facilities, faculty members, and instructional materials. of the 2. Provide students with relevant knowledge on basic education courses as prerequisites in understanding various allied Departmen programs. t 3. Produce graduates who could be licensed psychometricians, academicians, human resource managers, researchers, clinicians or any allied professions. 4. Engage in various research and extension activities that address global trends and societal demands, being aligned with the goals and objectives of the university. Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO)
The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. Apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. Conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. Promote the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. Promote environmental preservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. Become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles. Student Outcomes and Relationship to Program Educational Objectives Program Educational Objectives Code (based Program/Student Outcomes (based on the program CMO) on the program CMO) 1 2 3 4 5 The students should:

STANDARD TRANSMUTATION TABLE FOR ALL COURSES
96.7 – 100.0 1.00 93.4 – 96.6 1.25 90.1 - 93.30 1.50 86.7 – 90.0 1.75 83.4 – 86.6 2.00 80.1 – 83.3 2.25 76.7 – 80.0 2.50 73.4 – 76.6 2.75 70.00 – 73.3 3.00 50.0-69.9 4.00 Below 50 5.00 INC Passed the course but lack some requirements. Dropped If unexcused absence is at least 20% of the Total Class Hours. Total Class Hours/Semester: (3 unit Lec – 54 hrs; 2 unit Lec – 36 hrs) (1 unit Lab – 54 hrs; 2 units Lab – 108 hrs; 3 units Lab – 162 hrs)
CLASS POLICIES A. Attendance Students are not allowed to have 20% or more unexcused absences of the total face to face class hours; otherwise, they will be graded as “DROPPED”.
B. Classroom Decorum
During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 8. come to class on time.

V02-2020-07-01

During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during on-line activities, and 4. submit take home assignments on time.
C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced 2. Mid-term and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a mid-term or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity; b. due to illness or death in the family; and c. due to force majeure or natural calamities.
REFERENCES & SUPPLEMENTARY READINGS References:
Required Textbook/Workbook Peralta, E., Botor, N. & laude, T. (2019). Gender and Society: A Human Ecological Approach. Quezon City: Rex Bookstore
Other References: Hutchison, B. (2011). Human Sexualities. Annual Edition.Mc Graw Hills, New York. Oakley, A. (2016). Sex, Gender and Society. Routledge, New York. http://taylorandfrancis.com Wells, K. (2019). Modesto Junior College Modesto CA 95350
Supplementary Readings Republic Act 7877: Anti Sexual Harrassment Act of 1995 Republic Act 10627 Anti Bullying Republic Act 11313 Anti Bastos (Safe Spaces Act)

The three campuses shall endeavor to: Goals of the 1. provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright, and globally competitive graduates: College/ Campus 2. develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences, and technology to support instruction: and 3. develop and conduct extension activities that will empower local people and communities. The department shall endeavor to:
1. support the university’s mission and vision in providing globally competitive individuals through technological Objectives of advancements; the 2. equip students with knowledge in the field of information and computer technology; and Department 3. strengthen students’ skills through research development and extension activities that will endow their personal and social growth. 4. to deliver a gender-fair and gender-sensitive aligned instructions to students aligned with the university goals and objectives. Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO 25 s. 2015) The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental conservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles.

CLASS POLICIES A. Attendance Students are not allowed to have 20% or more unexcused absences of the total face to face class hours; otherwise, they will be graded as “DROPPED”.
B. Classroom Decorum During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 8. come to class on time.

During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during on-line activities, and 4. submit take home assignments on time.
C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Mid-term and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a mid-term or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity; b. due to illness or death in the family; and c. due to force majeure or natural calamities.

Pre- Lecture: ______________________________ requisites DCIT 23 Course Schedule Laboratory: ______________________________ Students are expected to live by and stand for the following University tenets:
TRUTH is demonstrated by the student’s objectivity and honesty during examinations, class activities and in the development of projects.
EXCELLENCE is exhibited by the students’ self-confidence, punctuality, diligence and commitment in the assigned tasks, class Core Values performance and other course requirements.
SERVICE is manifested by the students’ respect, rapport, fairness and cooperation in dealing with their peers and members of the community. In addition, they should exhibit love and respect for nature and support for the cause of humanity.
Goals of the The Campus shall endeavor to: College/

Campus 1. provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright, and globally competitive graduates; 2. develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences, and technology to support instruction; and 3. develop and conduct extension activities that will empower local people and communities. The department shall endeavor to:
1. support the university’s mission and vision in providing globally competitive individuals through technological Objectives advancements; of the 2. equip students with knowledge in the field of information technology; and Department 3. strengthen students’ skills through research development and extension activities that will endow their personal and social growth.
Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO)
The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can:
1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental conservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles.

CLASS POLICIES A. Attendance Students are not allowed to have 20% or more unexcused absences of the total face to face class hours; otherwise, they will be graded as “DROPPED”.
B. Classroom Decorum
During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and

Total Class Hours/Semester: 90 hours
CLASS POLICIES A. Attendance Students are not allowed to have 20% or more unexcused absences of the total face to face class hours; otherwise, they will be graded as “DROPPED”.
B. Classroom Decorum
During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and
V02-2020-07-01

8. come to class on time.
During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during on-line activities, and 4. submit take home assignments on time.
C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Mid-term and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a mid-term or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity; b. due to illness or death in the family; and c. due to force majeure or natural calamities. SERVICE is manifested by the students’ respect, rapport, fairness and cooperation in dealing with their peers and members of the community. In addition, they should exhibit love and respect for nature and support for the cause of humanity. The Campus shall endeavor to achieve the following goals: Goals of the College/ 1. Provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright, and globally competitive graduates; Campus 2. Develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences, and technology to support instruction; and 3. Develop and conduct extension activities that will empower people and communities. The department of Information Technology shall endeavor to:
Objectives 1. support the university’s mission and vision in providing globally competitive individuals through technological of the advancements; Department 2. equip students with knowledge in the field of information and computer technology; and 3. strengthen students’ skills through research development and extension activities that will endow their personal and social growth. Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO) The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. promote the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental conservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles. 50.0-69.9 4.00 Below 50 5.00 INC Passed the course but lack some requirements. Dropped If unexcused absence is at least 20% of the Total Class Hours. Total Class Hours/Semester: 2 unit Lec – 36 hrs 1 unit Lab – 54 hrs CLASS POLICIES A. Attendance Students are not allowed to have 20% or more unexcused absences of the total face to face class hours; otherwise, they will be graded as “DROPPED”. B. Classroom Decorum During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 8. come to class on time. During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during on-line activities, and 4. submit take home assignments on time. C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Mid-term and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a mid-term or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity;

COURSE SYLLABUS 1 Semester, AY 2020-2021 st Course Lecture ✔ Course Code DCIT 21 Introducing to Computing Type Credit Units 3 Title Laboratory ✔ This course provides an overview of the Computing Industry and Computing profession, including Research and Applications Course in different fields such as Biology, Sociology, Environment and Gaming: an Understanding ACM Requirements: an Description Appreciation of the history of computing: and Knowledge of the Key Components of Computer Systems ( Organization and Architecture), Malware, Computer, Security, Internet and Internet protocols, HTML 4/5 and CSS. TRUTH is demonstrated by the student’s objectivity and honesty during examinations, class activities and in the development of projects.

The three campuses shall endeavor to:
Goals of the 1. provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright, and globally competitive graduates: Campus 2. develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences, and technology to support instruction: and 3. develop and conduct extension activities that will empower local people and communities. 4. The department shall endeavor to: 1. support the university’s mission and vision in providing globally competitive individuals through technological advancements; Objectives of 2. equip students with knowledge in the field of information and computer technology; and the 3. strengthen students’ skills through research development and extension activities that will endow their personal and social Department growth. 4. to deliver a gender-fair and gender-sensitive aligned instructions to students aligned with the university goals and objectives. 5. Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO 25 s. 2015) The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental conservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles.

(1 unit Lab – 54 hrs; 2 units Lab – 108 hrs; 3 units Lab – 162 hrs)
CLASS POLICIES A. Attendance Students are not allowed to have 20% or more unexcused absences of the total face to face class hours; otherwise, they will be graded as “DROPPED”.
B. Classroom Decorum
During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 8. come to class on time.
During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during on-line activities, and 4. submit take home assignments on time.
C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Mid-term and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a mid-term or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity;
V02-2020-07-01

The three campuses shall endeavor to: Goals of the 1. provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright, and globally competitive graduates: Campus 2. develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences, and technology to support instruction: and 3. develop and conduct extension activities that will empower local people and communities. The department shall endeavor to: 1. support the university’s mission and vision in providing globally competitive individuals through technological advancements; Objectives of 2. equip students with knowledge in the field of information and computer technology; and the 3. strengthen students’ skills through research development and extension activities that will endow their personal and Department social growth. 4. to deliver a gender-fair and gender-sensitive aligned instructions to students aligned with the university goals and objectives.
Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO 25 s. 2015) The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental conservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles. B. Classroom Decorum During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times; 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times; 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 8. come to class on time. During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects, and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during online activities, and 4. submit take home assignments on time. C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Midterm and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a Midterm or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity; b. due to illness or death in the family; and c. due to force majeure or natural calamities. REFERENCES & SUPPLEMENTARY READINGS References: 1. Required Textbook/Workbook Y. Daniel Liang (2015), Introduction to Java Programming 10 Edition, Pearson Prentice Hall th Reges, S. & Stepp, M. (2011). Building Java Programs. A Back to Basic Approach. Pearson Prentice Hall 2. Laboratory Manual (if with laboratory) Cadenhead, Rogers, Lemay, Laura, Sams teach yourself java 2 in 21 days (4th ed.)

It shall produce professional, skilled and morally upright individuals for global competitiveness. TRECE MARTIRES CITY CAMPUS DEPARTMENT OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY
Students are expected to live by and stand for the following University tenets:
TRUTH is demonstrated by the student’s objectivity and honesty during examinations, class activities and in the development of projects.
EXCELLENCE is exhibited by the students’ self-confidence, punctuality, diligence and commitment in the assigned tasks, class performance Core Values and other course requirements.
SERVICE is manifested by the students’ respect, rapport, fairness and cooperation in dealing with their peers and members of the community. In addition, they should exhibit love and respect for nature and support for the cause of humanity.
The three campuses shall endeavor to:
Goals of the 1. Provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright and globally competitive graduates; Campus 2. Develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences and technology to support instruction; and 3. Develop and conduct extension activities that will empower people and communities.
The department shall endeavor to:
Objectives of the 1. support the university’s mission and vision in providing globally competitive individuals through technological advancements; 2. equip students with knowledge in the field of information and computer technology; and Department 3. strengthen students’ skills through research development and extension activities that will endow their personal and social growth.

Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO) The program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. promote the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental preservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles. COURSE SYLLABUS Second Semester, AY 2018-2019 Course Course Lecture  Code DCIT 23 Title Computer Programming 2 Type Laboratory  Credit Units 3 Course This course is a continuation of CC101 - Computer Programming 1. The emphasis is toe train students to design, implement, test and Description debug programs intended to solve computing problems using basic data structures and standard libraries. Pre- DCIT 22 Course Schedule Lecture: BSIT1-1(Tue 9:00-10:00) requisites Laboratory: BSIT1-1(Thurs 1:00-7:00) Student Outcomes and Relationship to Program Educational Objectives Program Educational Objectives (based on the program Program/Student Outcomes (based on the program CMO) CMO) 1 2 3 4 5 The students should: a. articulate and discuss the latest developments in the specific field of practice;      b. effectively communicate orally and in writing using both English and Filipino;      c. work effectively and independently in multi-disciplinary and multi-cultural teams;      d. act in recognition of professional, social, and ethical responsibility;      e. preserve and promote “Filipino historical and cultural heritage”;      analyze complex problems, and identify and define the computing requirements      f. needed to design an appropriate solution; g. apply computing and other knowledge domains to address real-world problems;      h. design and develop computing solutions using a system-level perspective; and      i. utilize modern computing tools.      Course Outcomes and Relationship to Student Outcomes Program Outcomes Addressed by the Course Program Outcomes Code After completing this course, the students must be able to: a b C d e f g h i 1. 3. clean the classroom before and after classes; 4. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 5. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 6. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 7. come to class on time. C. Computer Laboratory 1. Always log in BEFORE and AFTER using the laboratory room. A logbook is provided at the laboratory room. 2. Any defects/malfunctions which are observed while using any of the computer units in laboratory should be reported. 3. Eating is prohibited inside the laboratory room. 4. Computer games are absolutely not allowed. 5. No personal files or data shall be stored in the hard disk. 6. Any user caught or proven to have vandalized the facilities and damaged the equipment will be dealt with accordingly. 7. Bags and other things shall be deposited in the designated area provided in the laboratory before using the computer units. 8. Everyone is enjoined to keep the computers and the laboratory room in perfect condition. D. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Mid-term and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited.A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a mid-term or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity; b. due to illness or death in the family; and c. due to force majeure or natural calamities. MIDTERM EXAMINATION DCIT 23: Computer Programming 2
Name: Score: Course & Section: Date:
I. MULTIPLE CHOICE. Choose the letter of the correct answer. Write your answer on the space provided before the number. 1-2. This is a programming language that is high-level, obejct oriented and general-purpose computer programming language. a. Java c. Visual Basic b. C++ d. Python
3-4. Java is similar to what programming language to eliminate language feature. a. Java c. Visual Basic b. C++ d. Python
5-6. WORA means . a. write once, run anyplace c. write once, run anywhere b. wrote once, run anywhere d. write once, run anything
7-8. Java edition for developing desktop applications. a. Java SE c. Java ME b. Java EE
9-10. Java edition for applications which run on servers. a. Java SE c. Java ME b. Java EE
11-12. Java edition for applications which run on resource constrained devices like cellphones. a. Java SE c. Java ME b. Java EE
13-14. JRE stands for . a. Java Runtime Enterprise c. Java Runtime Environment b. Java Runtime Edition
15-16. JDK stands for a. Java Developmental Kit c. Java Development Kit b. Java Developed Kit
17-18. It helps the operating system to find where java is installed. a. PATH c. WORA b. WAY
V01-2018-10-01

TTTC-CF-03
19-20. Should start with lowercase letter and be a verb. a. class name c. method name b. variable name d. package name
21-22. Should start with uppercase letter and be a noun. a. class name c. method name b. variable name d. package name
23-24. Should start with uppercase letter and be an adjective. a. class name c. method name b. interface name d. package name
25-26. Should start with lowercase e.g. firstName, orderNumber. a. class name c. method name b. variable name d. package name
27-28. Primitive data types are predefined by the language and named by a keyword. a. true b. false
29-30. It represents one bit of information and have only two possible values. a. boolean c. char b. int d. float
II. Enumeration:
31-35. Features of Java Programming
36-45. Java Language keywords
46-50. Primitive data types

The three campuses shall endeavor to: Goals of the 1. provide high quality instruction in order to produce skilled, morally upright, and globally competitive graduates: Campus 2. develop and pursue advance research activities through arts, sciences, and technology to support instruction: and 3. develop and conduct extension activities that will empower local people and communities. The department shall endeavor to: 1. support the university’s mission and vision in providing globally competitive individuals through technological advancements; Objectives of 2. equip students with knowledge in the field of information and computer technology; and the 3. strengthen students’ skills through research development and extension activities that will endow their personal and Department social growth. 4. to deliver a gender-fair and gender-sensitive aligned instructions to students aligned with the university goals and objectives.
Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO 25 s. 2015) The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental conservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles. Individual Performance 3. Quizzes 4. Midterm Examination 5. Final Examination 6. Video presentation 7. Attendance *All exams must follow a Table of Specifications (TOS) and Rubrics for evaluation of student’ performance or projects. GRADING SYSTEM Grading system for 2 units lecture and 1 unit laboratory (i.e. DCIT 21; 3 units; Lec - 2 hrs & Lab - 3 hrs) Lecture – 60% Laboratory – 40%

Laboratory Class: 40% Laboratory Exam 30% Laboratory Activity 30% Project 40% Laboratory Grade 100%
Final Grade= (Laboratory Grade * 0.40) + (Lecture Grade * 0.60) STANDARD TRANSMUTATION TABLE FOR ALL COURSES 96.7 – 100.0 1.00 93.4 – 96.6 1.25 90.1 - 93.30 1.50 86.7 – 90.0 1.75 83.4 – 86.6 2.00 80.1 – 83.3 2.25 76.7 – 80.0 2.50 73.4 – 76.6 2.75 70.00 – 73.3 3.00 50.0-69.9 4.00 Below 50 5.00 INC Passed the course but lack some requirements. B. Classroom Decorum During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times; 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times; 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 8. come to class on time. During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects, and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during online activities, and 4. submit take home assignments on time. C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Midterm and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a Midterm or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity; b. due to illness or death in the family; and c. due to force majeure or natural calamities. Laboratory Manual (if with laboratory) Cadenhead, Rogers, Lemay, Laura, Sams teach yourself java 2 in 21 days (4th ed.)

COURSE SYLLABUS _1st_ Semester, AY _2020-2021_ Lecture ✓ Credit Course Code ITEC 101 Course Title E-Commerce Type 3 Laboratory ✓ Units This course focuses on principles of e-commerce from a business perspective, providing an overview of business and technology topics, business models, virtual value chains and social innovation and marketing strategies. In addition, Course some of the major issues associated with e-commerce - security, privacy, intellectual property rights, authentication, Description encryption, acceptable use policies, and legal liabilities - will be explored. Students will build their own web presence and market it using an online platform. Program Educational Objectives (based on the program CMO) The Bachelor of Science in Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can: 1. apply knowledge of utilization of both hardware and software technologies involving planning, installing, customizing, operating, managing and administering, and maintaining information technology infrastructure that provides computing solutions to address the needs of an organization; 2. conduct relevant researches ad extension program activities in the field of information technology; 3. promote the development and transfer of appropriate information technology; 4. promote environmental conservation and protection on projects and enterprises related to information technology; and 5. become morally upright IT professionals with primary or secondary job roles.

CLASS POLICIES A. Attendance Students are not allowed to have 20% or more unexcused absences of the total face to face class hours; otherwise, they will be graded as “DROPPED”.
B. Classroom Decorum
During face to face mode Students are required to: 1. wear identification cards at all times; 2. wear face mask at all times 3. observe physical/social distancing at all times 4. clean the classroom before and after classes; 5. avoid unnecessary noise that might disturb other classes; 6. practice good manners and right conduct at all times; 7. practice gender sensitivity and awareness inside the classroom; and 8. come to class on time.
During distance mode Students are required to: 1. sign an honor system pledge; 2. avoid giving or receiving unauthorized aid of any kind on their examinations, papers, projects and assignments, 3. observe proper netiquette during on-line activities, and

4. submit take home assignments on time.
C. Examination/ Evaluation 1. Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. 2. Mid-term and Final Examinations are scheduled. 3. Cheating is strictly prohibited. A student who is caught cheating will be given a score of ”0” for the first offense. For the second offense, the student will be automatically given a failing grade in the subject. 4. Students who will miss a mid-term or final examination, a laboratory exercise or a class project may be excused and allowed to take a special exam, conduct a laboratory exercise or pass a class project for any of the following reasons: a. participation in a University/College-approved field trip or activity; b. due to illness or death in the family; and c. due to force majeure or natural calamities.

Title of the Study: Virtual Interaction in Teaching and Learning Environment (V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of Research Subject
I. SHORT BACKGROUND / DESCRIPTION OF THE STUDY
The Philippines has started to make headway in education through the policies that
aim to expand access and improve quality. The need for human capital development has been
the main motivation behind such educational reforms, as detailed in the current
administration’s Philippine Development Plan (PDP) 2017-2022. Despite notable gains, work
remains, especially in terms of academic performance, the number of educational facilities
and participation rates. To address these issues, the government has significantly increased
education expenditure over the years, initiated structural changes in basic and higher
education, and intensified partnerships with the private sector and industry.
The education system consists of the three components: basic education, higher
education and the technical and vocational education and training (TVET). The basic
education directed by the Department of Education (DepEd) has undergone a major change
in which Kindergarten is mandated in the elementary curriculum and the Enhanced Basic
Education Act of 2013, also known as the K-12 law, made attending secondary school
mandatory and extended the curriculum by two years. On other hand, higher education

directed by the Commission of Higher Education (CHED) which includes undergraduate and
postgraduate programs.
Technology has made it possible for us to gain access to diverse and abundant
information. Students can harness this, evaluate which ones are accurate and have
significance, and use it to address a certain issue. Alternative Delivery Modes (ADM) was
implemented by DepEd to address the problem on classroom congestion and other situations
and circumstances which prevent children from going to and staying in school.
Virtual learning is a learning experience that is enhanced through utilizing computers
and/or internet both outside and inside the facilities of the educational organization. The
instructions most commonly take place in an online environment the teaching activities are
carried out online whereby the teachers and learners are physically separated.
According to Tech Target (2019), a virtual learning environment (VLE) could be a set
of teaching and learning tools designed to reinforce a student's learning expertise together
with computers and also the web within the learning method. The principal parts of a VLE
package embrace information mapping, student following, on-line support for each teacher
and student, transmission (e-mail, rib discussions, chat, net publishing), and web links to
outside information resources.
In addition, Koskela et al. (2005) found out, that the number of latest virtual learning
environments (VLEs) is increasing and that are being publicized as an answer for remote and
cross-border education. Students will perform a large vary of exercises with a computer-based
learning setting. This can be extraordinarily necessary once the tasks cannot be experienced
in reality, as an example because of their unsafe nature.
In the Philippine, the concept of e-Learning is relatively new due to lack of infrastructure
and high cost of internet access. Public education suffers from shortages or lack of computers
and internet access. However, the high regard for better quality education among Filipinos can
be manifested on various government programs and policies that promote online learning into
curriculum development.

Methods of Research subject is one of the subjects injected in all the programs in the
tertiary education. It aims to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills through
qualitative and quantitative research for college students regardless of their program.
Research and development (R & D) is one of the necessary fields for an industry or
company to survive. Whether a new or established company, they need to invest in R & D, so
what more for a country?
Innovation is a strategy needed to have a successful R & D, which requires innovative
people. According to Patalinhug (2003), Philippine innovation system requires the
collaboration of the university and relevant industry associated with the courses provided by
the school. He further stressed, that students who are the future workers of the state will
appreciate the importance of innovation, do a little bit of R & D activities.
Those points of view, were considered by the researchers, the reason for choosing
Methods of Research subject to pilot VITLE.
With this, VITLE would focus on developing an alternative virtual learning program for
college students in Methods of Research subject. Critical to achieving success in this area is
the training of learners that includes providing appropriate instruction and continuing updates,
considering the dynamic nature of developments in research.
The proposed alternative learning system is a virtual learning environment that could
level up a modern-day method of teaching-leaning delivery that saves time and space, has
economic value, and considers convenience of the teachers and learners.

III. BRIEF SUMMARY OF FINDINGS
Research Objective 1:
The objective number 1 of the study is to design the Virtual Interaction in Teaching and
Learning Environment (V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of Research Subject.
Data Collected: Completed
Findings:
Virtual Interaction in Teaching and Learning Environment (V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of
Research Subject is designed to enable a new and efficient way of interacting with students
academically with the use of technology.
By using computers as the medium of learning and either local or online servers as
database this system can improve the craft of educators by exploring a digitized approach to
meet the expectations upon its learners. With the efficiency and convenience that the modern
technology offers, the study can improve the method of teaching of the instructors for a more
interesting, engaging and effective results.

Methodology
Source: http://ebeescorp.com/img/agile.jpg
Figure 1. Agile Development Method of Virtual Interaction in Teaching and Learning
Environment (V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of Research Subject
Stage 1
The development process of V.I.T.L.E. in MoR is conducted using the agile method.
Initially the researchers created the user interface (UI) of the website to visualize the flow and
process of the system and to have an idea on how to approach the user experience (UX).
Stage 2
Upon the finalization of the frontend of V.I.T.L.E. in MoR the researchers begin
developing the functionality of the system together with its features. Integration and testing
took place in this phase of the process and continues up until the researchers finalize the
functionality development of the system and pass the integration and testing.

Stage 3
The researchers commence a test run of the system to using localhost server to gather
data regarding the performance of the system, after that the researchers gathered data from
the test run to further improve the performance of the system inclined from the collected data
from the test run. Test runs commence always after the researchers successfully applied the
changes in the system up until the researchers finally reach the final phase of the process
where all the features of the system are fully functional and the UI and UX are finalize, test
runs are then concluded.
Testing
Test runs are conducted by the researchers using a localhost server where the system is
simulated and put through a series of testing for the researchers to see if there are bugs and
errors in the systems functionality and interface.
Research Objective 2: The objective number 2 of the study is to develop the Virtual Interaction in Teaching
and Learning Environment (V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of Research Subject website as designed
with the used of the framework Admin LTE and programming languages HTML, CSS and
JavaScript.
Data Collected: Completed
Findings:
V.I.T.L.E. in MoR is developed using a website framework named Admin LTE with
Hypertext Markup Language (HTML), Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) and JavaScript used to
fully develop the frontend of the system which includes the UI and UX and Hypertext

Preprocessor (PHP) and MySQL for the backend of the system where data can be added,
deleted, updated and stored in the database.
Project Structure
Virtual Interaction in Teaching and Learning Environment (V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of Research Subject
Figure 2. HIPO Diagram of Virtual Interaction in Teaching and Learning Environment
(V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of Research Subject
Figure 2 illustrates all of the pages that the V.I.T.L.E. in MoR possess. HIPO diagram
visualizes the three main pages of the system after the login page which are the administrator
panel, the instructor profile and the student profile.
After logging in using the administrators credentials the system will lead the user to the
administrator panel where four tabs can be viewed, the overview tab, classes tab, instructors

tab and the students tab. In the default tab which is the overview, the administrator can see
the summary of the systems data, that includes the total number of students, total number of
instructors and the existing classes registered in the system as well as the instructors assigned
in each class and the number of students in each class. In the classes tab, the administrator
can view all of the registered classes in the system and also the admin can update the class
as well as delete them. In the instructors tab the administrator can view all of the registered
instructors account, the admin can also update the instructor’s account information, change
its password and delete the account of the instructor. In the students tab the administrator can
view all of the registered student’s account, the admin can also update the student’s account
information, change its password and delete the account of the student.
In the instructor profile, three tabs can be viewed the activity tab, students tab and the
quizzes tab. In the activity tab the instructor can view all of the currently uploaded lessons and
quizzes for the class. In the students tab the instructor can view the full list of the registered
students in his/her class and also monitor who’s online or offline. In the quizzes tab the
instructor can view the quiz records of his/her students.
In the student profile the page only has one tab which is the activity tab, in here the
students can view the uploaded lesson of their instructor and the students can download the
learning material also the students can view and answer the quizzes uploaded also by their
instructor.

Capabilities and Limitations
The capabilities of Virtual Interaction in Teaching and Learning Environment
(V.I.T.L.E.) in Methods of Research Subject website are as follows:
1. It offers a new platform where instructors can further educate their students is a much
efficient and interactive manner.
2. Classes in this system can easily be managed by adding, updating and even deleting. 3. Instructors and students in this system can easily be managed by adding, updating,
changing password and even deleting,
4. `monitoring the classes, instructors and student using this system provides
convenience with the use of the administrator panel overview.
5. Interaction from the instructor to student and vice versa is made possible by the chat
feature of the system.
6. Instructors can upload their PDF file learning materials as well as quizzes in the system
for the students.
7. Instructors can easily manage their lessons by adding, viewing, downloading and/or
deleting it, as for quizzes the instructors can add, view and/or even delete it.
8. Instructors can easily register new students to her class in case a student is not
automatically registered by the administrator. 9. Instructors and student can freely change the password and display picture of their
own accounts.
10. Students can view and download the lessons uploaded by the instructor as well as
view and answer the quizzes.
However, the following are the limitations of the project:
1. Instructors can only upload PDF file format learning materials for their lessons.

2. Only multiple choice type of quizzes can be uploaded in the system.

IV. INSIGHTS
We have encountered quiet a lot of challenges along the way in doing this research,
one of such is the lack of knowledge in this particular branch of information technology which
is web development. Not everything is taught inside the four corners of our lecture rooms or
laboratories, we know that but learning things during this classes is not just the only thing that
is important we know then realize that picking a certain field in your degree where you can
utilize your skills at most is necessary when it comes to choosing a topic of your research.
Lacking the skill set we need to conclude this research force us to seek new and
different sources of learning focused in web development to gain the knowledge that our
research requires.
Finalizing our research is a much harder due to the restrictions on the things that we
can do freely due to the implementation of the Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as
precaution to the COVID-19 pandemic. These restrictions dramatically decreased the rate of
our progress in these recent months and press us to communicate online. Truly no one can
delay the future and the future calls for the new normal to be adapted.

Overall, our journey in concluding this research is an irregular, challenging and
unexpected but at the same time necessary and fruitful.

T3 Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar-Workshop July 30, 2019 Venue: International House II, CvSU-Main Campus
The T3 Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar-Workshop is an academic capability training enhancement usually conducted on a yearly basis in the campus which primary goal is to enhance T3 faculty members’ teaching capabilities. This is usually held prior to the opening of classes. The highlights of the activity this year were on mental health and orientation on academic and administrative policies which was held last July 30, 2019 at the Cavite State University-Main Campus, International House 1.
I. Morning Session The morning program officially started at 9am with an opening prayer and the singing of the national anthem. Prof. Noel A. Sedigo welcomed all participants and guest lecturers. He also gave brief overview of the topics to be covered for the rest of the day. After the Dean’s talk, the lecture proper commenced. It begun with a one-hour Deep Breathing exercise facilitated by Ms, Amida Chara Rosario N. Wolski, CEO of Radha Kunda Wellness. This particular exercise promotes mental relaxation through context of proper breathing. This was followed by the first lecture on “Understanding Mental Health in the workplace” presented by Ms. Yolanda T. Padilla, Assistant Manager for HR from BBT Online Global, Inc. Then, Ms. Wolski took charged in explaining and demonstrating through another set of exercise on how to be able to develop “Mindfulness for Mental Wellness”. The participants were also subjected to personality check test on mindfulness. The last activity in the morning finished off with a yoga/meditation session for Happiness and Fulfillment in Life led by Mr. Thomas F. Wolski, co-founder and CEO of Nature’s Power Nutraceuticals Corporation. The guest lecturers were then awarded with certificate of recognition and token of gratitude then followed by a photo-opt with the participants. It was a fruitful morning session indeed having such mind-body relaxing activity. A different and new experience for all faculty members of T3 campuses. The morning program ended exactly 12:00 noon.
II. Lunch Break- 12:01-1:00
III. Afternoon Session After a sumptuous meal during lunch break, the afternoon activity immediately proceeded starting off with the introduction of the key officials of the T3 campuses. Faculty members per department were also introduced by their respective department chairperson. The next part of the program was intended for lectures on the administrative and academic policies. Ms Shaine C. Hayag, HR Coordinator of General Trias City Campus discussed RA 6713/ Code of Conduct and Ethical Standards for Public Officials and Employees, Prof. Mildred A. Sebastian, T3 Quality Assurance Coordinator gave emphasis and reorientation on the Course Syllabi

Preparation and Prof. Vienna Mi A. Feranil briefly oriented the faculty on the University VMGO. After these series of lectures, faculty members were instructed to gather along with other faculty members of their respective department to finalize the faculty load with a little workshop on the course syllabi. After the workshop, this whole day activity ended with a closing remarks shared by Ms. Alelie B. Diato, Campus Coordinator of General Trias City, Campus.

T3 Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar Documentation January 30-31, 2019, International House 1, CvSU-Main Campus
Objectives
The activity aims to provide the faculty members the latest trends in Higher Education 4.0, as well as research and extension, in order to help them provide high quality instruction, develop and pursue advanced research activities, and design and conduct extension activities that will empower people and communities.
Rationale
The Higher Education 4.0 trends and future perspectives for teaching and learning are equally affected by the rapid changes we are facing today. These trends are significant to meet the future needs and challenges in education through the pervasive application of Information and Communication Technology (ICT).
Discussion and dissemination of Higher Education 4.0 could enhance teachers’ capability since 74 percent of the faculty members in the T3 Campuses are not an education graduate and/or do not belong in any professional education organization that could aid in the discussion.
To date, only 13 percent of the T3 Campuses faculty members are engaged in research activity because some do not have enough understanding and enlightenment on the research proposal preparation. Although all permanent faculty members are involved in community activities/services, they have limited knowledge on how to prepare a comprehensive extension activity proposal.
Overview
On January 30-31, 2019, the teachers and staff of the T3 Campuses, Tanza, General Trias City, and Trece Martires City, joined together for this semester’s Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar Workshop at International House I, Cavite State University, Indang Cavite from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The two-day seminar workshop featured five guest speakers who covered various topics promoting the growth and development of teachers in the academe.
The capability enhancement seminar was designed to promote continuous development of teachers as they gear up for the second semester of school year 2018-2019. The guest speakers who tackled various topics that centered on becoming effective teachers in our country’s relatively new period of outcomes-based education and technology-driven teaching strategy, successfully prepped the T3 faculty in their various departments for the many challenges that lay ahead of them this semester.

Day 1
For Day 1 of the seminar, the opening prayer was led by Tanza General Education Department faculty, Mr. Mark Joel C. Sibulo, while the welcome remarks was given by Prof. Noel A. Sedigo, T3 Campus Administrator. Vice President for Academic Affairs Dr. Camilo A. Polinga, thru Ms. Agnes Nuestro, gave his inspirational message to all seminar participants. Afterwards, Prof. Vienna Mi A. Feranil, T3 Curriculum Development and Instruction Head gave her talk on leveling the expectations and objectives of the T3 faculty in order to properly align themselves to the goals of the university, the campus, as well as their respective departments.
The first resource person, Chair of CED Teacher Education Department, Prof. Jayson R. Maniacop (introduced by Prof. Mildred A. Sebastian, T3 Teacher Education Department Chair), discussed his topic on Syllabus Preparation. For the next session, the second resource person and Dean of the College of Education, Dr. Cecilia A. Banaag (introduced by Ms. Joyce Erika S. Senaris, T3 Department of Information Technology Chair) delivered her topic on Teaching Strategies and Classroom Management.

T3 Campuses spearhead first Arduino technology forum and exhibit at Rolle Hall By Suzette A. Quesada-Magano, Ph.D.
The 1 Cavite Arduino Technology Research Forum and Exhibit was held on April 22, 2019 st from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. at the Santiago M. Rolle Hall, CvSU-Main Campus, Indang Cavite. The event was organized by the Office of the Vice-President for Research and Extension (OVPRE) and College of Engineering and Information Technology, with the help of a number of sponsors: American Spaces Philippines, Fablab Manila, Sparkfruit Electronics, LEENTECH Network Solutions, RoboRAVE Philippines, and LITL.
The said activity’s aim was to expose students and teachers to an event where they could accomplish the following goals: exhibit and present their Arduino-based research, interact and collaborate with other Cavite schools as well as nearby cities and provinces, and update themselves on the current application of Arduino technology on instruction, research, enterprise, and information technology. The local research forum was conducted in preparation for a much bigger event in the near future: an international conference to be held at CvSU in 2020. The said future project was meant to be accomplished in partnership with the American Center, Manila and American Spaces Philippines.
The program began with a doxology led by Pamela Daphne R. Busog, CvSU-Trece Martires City Campus Extension Coordinator, followed by the singing of the Philippine National Anthem led by Steven G. Quisto, a BS Information Technology student. The opening remarks were given by T3 Campus Administrator, Prof. Noel A. Sedigo and the introduction of the CvSU Administration Council by Prof. Allan Robert C. Solis, Director of the Public Information and Community Relations Office. Messages to the seminar’s participants were given by the following guest speakers: Dr. David L. Cero, Dean of the College of Engineering and Information Technology, Dr. Camilo A. Polinga, Vice President for Academic Affairs, Dr. Ruel M. Mojica, Vice President for Research and Extension, and the University’s very own president, Dr. Hernando D. Robles. The certificate for the keynote speaker was awarded by the University President himself, together with the T3 Campus Administrator, Prof. Sedigo.
T3 MIS Officer Keno A. Villavicencio introduced the first keynote speaker, Richard F. Prodigalidad, President and CEO of LEENTECH Network Solutions, a company that specializes in mobile application design and development, digital marketing and consultation, and cloud server and management solutions. A Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) between LEENTECH and Cavite State University was signed afterwards. The morning plenary session featured the following topics: Arduino, Education, and Training (led by guest speaker Arvin S. Buendia, Robotics Specialist for the CIIT College of Arts and Technology and author of a few Arduino- based robotics textbooks), Arduino Integration on Laboratory Instruction (led by Keno A. Villavicencio, IT instructor of CvSU-T3 and Arduino-based research presenter for the 2019 International Conference on Open and Distance e-Learning in Taiwan), Arduino Local and International Competitions (led by Mervin A. Boco, Robotics Coordinator of Tagaytay City Science High School and International and National Robotics Competitions Champion and Awardee in Australia, Singapore, Taiwan, Indonesia, and the Philippines).
For the afternoon session, participating schools and companies featured their works in the Arduino oral-based and display-based project presentation portion, followed by the competition named “Arduinothon.” The next keynote speaker was Jeanie M. Duwan, Assistant Cultural Affairs Officer for the US Embassy, who was later proceeded by a new set of guest speakers for the following topics for discussion: American Spaces (led by Xavier E. Lara, Director of American Spaces Philippines), Arduino International Association and Events (led by Michael

Julius G. Hayag, Director of RoboRAVE Philippines), and Arduino Fabrication, Enterprise, and Markets (led by Engr. Cezar R. Calayo, General Manager of CRV Embedded System Design for Sparkfruit Electronics Enterprise and Fablab Manila). The certificates were then awarded by Prof. Noel A. Sedigo, Pamela Daphne R. Busog, adviser for the student organization, League of IT Leaders, Roncesvalle J. Caipang, T3 Research Coordinator, and Joyce Erika S. Senaris, T3 Chairperson for the Department of Information Technology.
The awards for the winners of the Arduino-based Oral Presentation competition, the Arduino- based Display Presentation competition, and the Arduinothon were given after the awarding of the certificate to the second keynote speaker, while the closing remarks were given by Keno A. Villavicencio, the overall in-charge of the said event. The forum and exhibit was concluded by the singing of the CvSU hymn led by Pamela Daphne R. Busog.
The theme of the event, “Translating Ideas into Innovation” paved the way for interesting avenues for discussion among IT practitioners and aspiring professionals, which gave the participants of the forum a glimpse into the competitive world of the IT industry. Joseph O. Sabaybay, CvSU-Tanza Campus IT Instructor and participant of the Arduino forum, had great things to say about his experience of the said event: “The first Cavite Arduino technology research forum and exhibit was a great and informative seminar as well as a good platform for students to showcase their talents and passion for robotics and the like, especially for the younger students—those in senior high school. Through the effort of Sir Keno, we became connected and had a MOA with local and international companies and the government that deals with Arduino technology.” The event was indeed a success as it established solidarity among students, practitioners, and enthusiasts of Arduino technology in the IT industry—a hopeful turnout at a time where young professionals are expected to become more competitive in the digital world.

T3 Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar-Workshop July 30, 2019 Venue: International House II, CvSU-Main Campus
The T3 Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar-Workshop is an academic capability training enhancement usually conducted on a yearly basis in the campus which primary goal is to enhance T3 faculty members’ teaching capabilities. This is usually held prior to the opening of classes. The highlights of the activity this year were on mental health and orientation on academic and administrative policies which was held last July 30, 2019 at the Cavite State University-Main Campus, International House 1.
I. Morning Session The morning program officially started at 9am with an opening prayer and the singing of the national anthem. Prof. Noel A. Sedigo welcomed all participants and guest lecturers. He also gave brief overview of the topics to be covered for the rest of the day. After the Dean’s talk, the lecture proper commenced. It begun with a one-hour Deep Breathing exercise facilitated by Ms, Amida Chara Rosario N. Wolski, CEO of Radha Kunda Wellness. This particular exercise promotes mental relaxation through context of proper breathing. This was followed by the first lecture on “Understanding Mental Health in the workplace” presented by Ms. Yolanda T. Padilla, Assistant Manager for HR from BBT Online Global, Inc. Then, Ms. Wolski took charged in explaining and demonstrating through another set of exercise on how to be able to develop “Mindfulness for Mental Wellness”. The participants were also subjected to personality check test on mindfulness. The last activity in the morning finished off with a yoga/meditation session for Happiness and Fulfillment in Life led by Mr. Thomas F. Wolski, co-founder and CEO of Nature’s Power Nutraceuticals Corporation. The guest lecturers were then awarded with certificate of recognition and token of gratitude then followed by a photo-opt with the participants. It was a fruitful morning session indeed having such mind-body relaxing activity. A different and new experience for all faculty members of T3 campuses. The morning program ended exactly 12:00 noon.
II. Lunch Break- 12:01-1:00
III. Afternoon Session After a sumptuous meal during lunch break, the afternoon activity immediately proceeded starting off with the introduction of the key officials of the T3 campuses. Faculty members per department were also introduced by their respective department chairperson. The next part of the program was intended for lectures on the administrative and academic policies. Ms Shaine C. Hayag, HR Coordinator of General Trias City Campus discussed RA 6713/ Code of Conduct and Ethical Standards for Public Officials and Employees, Prof. Mildred A. Sebastian, T3 Quality Assurance Coordinator gave emphasis and reorientation on the Course Syllabi

Preparation and Prof. Vienna Mi A. Feranil briefly oriented the faculty on the University VMGO. After these series of lectures, faculty members were instructed to gather along with other faculty members of their respective department to finalize the faculty load with a little workshop on the course syllabi. After the workshop, this whole day activity ended with a closing remarks shared by Ms. Alelie B. Diato, Campus Coordinator of General Trias City, Campus.

T3 Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar Documentation January 30-31, 2019, International House 1, CvSU-Main Campus
Objectives
The activity aims to provide the faculty members the latest trends in Higher Education 4.0, as well as research and extension, in order to help them provide high quality instruction, develop and pursue advanced research activities, and design and conduct extension activities that will empower people and communities.
Rationale
The Higher Education 4.0 trends and future perspectives for teaching and learning are equally affected by the rapid changes we are facing today. These trends are significant to meet the future needs and challenges in education through the pervasive application of Information and Communication Technology (ICT).
Discussion and dissemination of Higher Education 4.0 could enhance teachers’ capability since 74 percent of the faculty members in the T3 Campuses are not an education graduate and/or do not belong in any professional education organization that could aid in the discussion.
To date, only 13 percent of the T3 Campuses faculty members are engaged in research activity because some do not have enough understanding and enlightenment on the research proposal preparation. Although all permanent faculty members are involved in community activities/services, they have limited knowledge on how to prepare a comprehensive extension activity proposal.
Overview
On January 30-31, 2019, the teachers and staff of the T3 Campuses, Tanza, General Trias City, and Trece Martires City, joined together for this semester’s Teachers’ Capability Enhancement Seminar Workshop at International House I, Cavite State University, Indang Cavite from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The two-day seminar workshop featured five guest speakers who covered various topics promoting the growth and development of teachers in the academe.
The capability enhancement seminar was designed to promote continuous development of teachers as they gear up for the second semester of school year 2018-2019. The guest speakers who tackled various topics that centered on becoming effective teachers in our country’s relatively new period of outcomes-based education and technology-driven teaching strategy, successfully prepped the T3 faculty in their various departments for the many challenges that lay ahead of them this semester.

Day 1
For Day 1 of the seminar, the opening prayer was led by Tanza General Education Department faculty, Mr. Mark Joel C. Sibulo, while the welcome remarks was given by Prof. Noel A. Sedigo, T3 Campus Administrator. Vice President for Academic Affairs Dr. Camilo A. Polinga, thru Ms. Agnes Nuestro, gave his inspirational message to all seminar participants. Afterwards, Prof. Vienna Mi A. Feranil, T3 Curriculum Development and Instruction Head gave her talk on leveling the expectations and objectives of the T3 faculty in order to properly align themselves to the goals of the university, the campus, as well as their respective departments.
The first resource person, Chair of CED Teacher Education Department, Prof. Jayson R. Maniacop (introduced by Prof. Mildred A. Sebastian, T3 Teacher Education Department Chair), discussed his topic on Syllabus Preparation. For the next session, the second resource person and Dean of the College of Education, Dr. Cecilia A. Banaag (introduced by Ms. Joyce Erika S. Senaris, T3 Department of Information Technology Chair) delivered her topic on Teaching Strategies and Classroom Management.
